fields.summary: Restored instances are missing expiry time

fields.description:
After an HA Failover, the following occurred:

* Walrus "lost" some images that were registered
* Instances were taking a really long time to launch (~ 1 hour)
fields.summary: After HA Failover, Walrus loses Registered Images and Instances Are Very Slow To Launch
fields.environment:
*HA Setup*

* 2 x CLC/Walrus/CC/SC
* Equallogic for SC HA

comments.body:
Chris,
   could you link this to the appropriate ticket (or tell us which one) and let us know if there is any additional post mortem analysis you an share?

Slow response times may have been cause by database failing transactions, as seen in the cloud-output.log files. Additionally, it was discovered instances running on the NCs that were unknown to the CLC. General correction steps included terminating instances and ensuring the CLC were operating as expected in HA mode. After corrective actions were taken through out the system, the run instances command behavior returned to an acceptable response time.

can we get some set of confirmation if we believe this issue is resolved or at least less likely to occur?  Ken's latest comments have been very helpful.  But can this issue be considered resolved or should we keep it open and assigned as more work is needed?

[~dstagnaro] I think there are a number of factors here which contributed to the problem:
# Instance restore causes an error which leaked database connections
# Order with which services are restarted looks like it lead to syncing from a stale copy of the system database

For 3.2.0 a number of fixes were made to address the above two issues. I can point out fixes linked to the issue EUCA-4366 and [~kedwards] and [~sjones] could say more about instance restore and CLC startup ordering.
Bugs I worked on related to instance restore that are fixed in 3.2 are EUCA-3795, EUCA-3809, EUCA-3833, EUCA-3834, EUCA-3866, EUCA-3879, EUCA-4171, EUCA-4172

Per [~decker], this is believed to be fixed, but we have no reproduction case to use for validation.

[~decker], can you confirm which version this was fixed in?  

[~hspencer], would you be able to help with this verification?  It looks like we'll need to do this at the customer if we have no way to reproduce in house.  

Thanks.

There are two issues identified here:

# Walrus "loses" images.
# Instances taking long time to start.

The second is addressed by the below referenced series of commits.

The first has been observed but we have been unable to reproduce the condition.  Fixes have been made to the handling of DB error conditions which may have addressed this problem, but we cannot verify that to be the case w/o a reproduction.  Additionally, other DB related fixes have been identified in the interim which may also speak to this problem (but, again, would need a reproduction case to verify).

thanks.
chris


commit dff34812327d71946501eec86a05c6ab23c1c180
Author: Ken Edwards <ken.edwards@eucalyptus.com>
Date:   Mon Oct 29 10:57:44 2012 -0700

    Fix to network handling during instance restore.
    
    - Add debug output for the reported instance state given to restore
    - Add precondition check before trying to restore a possibly bad
      instance definition
    - Allocate index in same tx as vm instance during restore
    - Restore networks in same tx as vm instance during restore
    - Skip restore while a cluster is enabling
    - Use the instance owner as owner for orpha-groups
    - Fix bug where extant network was not being set correctly when
      reclaimed for an existing group

commit 4c2921e4549cdd17afc06fad520e7df8c2f40f4f
Author: Steve Jones <steve.jones@eucalyptus.com>
Date:   Thu Nov 15 19:04:31 2012 -0800

    Updated instance image identifier for an unknown image (EUCA-4157)
    
    We now use the value 'emi-00000000' instead of '-' for the identifier of
    an unknown image. This can occur on restore of an instance if the
    related image is deregistered or removed.
    
    The identifier is visible when describing instances and via the instance
    meta-data.
    
    Fixes EUCA-4157

commit e9d82c4e176c5231f5adf38b2f19f263feb493d0
Author: Steve Jones <steve.jones@eucalyptus.com>
Date:   Thu Nov 1 16:35:34 2012 -0700

    Instance restoration with missing/deregistered image (EUCA-3834)
    
    Instance restore was failing if the image used by the instance was
    missing or deregistered.
    
    The fix adds a new 'UnavailableImageInfo' which is used to create a fake
    bootset for use when initializing the instance on restoration. When the
    instance is saved we do not persist any information for the
    'machineImage' in the boot record. The 'UnavailableImageInfo' provides a
    way to preserve the platform information for the restored instance.
    
    When describing an instance we will show nothing for the kernel or
    ramdisk image identifiers. For the machine image identifier we will
    display a dash.
    
    The metadata service is updated to return a dash for the image
    identifier if not available.
    
    Fixes EUCA-3834

commit 2e9764e7a63ee1342c43d19a7d84ff40093656c4
Author: Steve Jones <steve.jones@eucalyptus.com>
Date:   Fri Oct 19 16:37:00 2012 -0700

    Instance restore fixes for terminated instances and address restoration.
    
    The "reason" for termination on expiry is now correctly set, we were
    recording expiry as user termination.
    
    We now check the reason for termination when a terminated instance is
    reported, if the reason was expiry then we restore the instance and then
    remove the instance from the terminated cache.
    
    Restoration of the instance is modified to perform network and network
    index restoration within the transaction so it can be rolled back on
    failure and to void non-persistent entities being passed to persist
    (when persisting the instance)
    
    Address restoration is updated so that when we assign an allocated
    address to the restored instance we also update the address state to
    reflect this assignment. We also now handle restoration of addresses
    when the address is not currently active. In this case the address is
    assigned to the instance as a system address.
    
    In VmInstance.doUpdate:~1530 there was a duplicated case that has been
    removed.
    
    Fixes EUCA-3833, EUCA-3866, EUCA-3879
[~decker] what is the right step here? Should push [~chuck] for a fix in 3.3.1? Do you have enough info? Should we close it till we get more data?

(edited: after birthing this rant I'm gonna mention [~viglesias] and [~clc-team], too) 

[~graziano] to the best of my knowledge the issues related to instance state have been addressed between 3.2.1 and 3.3.0.  With regard to the image registrations, while we have seen it, we have never been able to systematically reproduce the bug in question.  That is, even if we did have a /"fix"/ we would not be able to verify and accept it.

That says we need to create the reproduction test case first.  We need to take the reproduction inter-arrival time from _months_ down to _hours/minutes_ in a single system.  If we are able to reproduce the problem even a couple of times we will either have a reasonable test case or the kind of controlled environment we need to create a focused synthetic test case.  I would suggest:

h5. Attack 3.2.0 Instance restore
I know we have seen this in the wild w/ 3.2.0.  In 3.2.0 it may be that instance restore was the main trigger for the failure.  We can test that in this scenario:
* Split component HA w/ 2 NCs ([CLC_1][CLC_2][WS_1][WS_2][CC_1,SC_1][CC_2,SC_2][NC_1][NC_2]; each bracket being a host)
# START w/ all COMPONENT_1 services as ENABLED and all COMPONENT_2 services up and DISABLED (healthy)
# THEN Run an instance, call it VM_1, and where ever that VM_1 runs we call the host NC_1
# THEN Induce a failure which partitions CLC_1/CC_1 from NC_1
# THEN Induce a failure which partitions the CLC_1 from CLC_2
# THEN Launch a conflicting instance, VM_2 -- which will land on NC_2, the effervescent surviving node controller
# THEN Resolve the partitions between CLC_1 and CLC_2 (this will trigger a resync event for CLC_2)
# THEN Resolve the partitions between CLC_1/CC_1 and NC_1 (this will trigger a restore event for the orphaned instance VM_1)
# THEN Check the system for consistency

h5. Parameter space

Even in this limited scenario there is a parameter space we would have to explore.  For example, steps #3, #4, and #5 the legitimate orderings are: (345),(435),(453) [note: this last case only makes sense if VM_2 is launched using CLC_2 after the partition at step #4].  The same ordering applies for #6 and #7.  This gives a single test pass which involves 6 orderings.  Given that a single ordering will take on the order of many minutes to test against (because it involves timeouts and syncs) time saving tricks will have to be used.

h5. Other similar test-needing areas
* Walrus image uploads & registrations which overlap w/ partitions/failovers between either the walrus hosts and/or the CLC hosts
* Volume creations or attachments which overlap with instance orphaning/restoration or partitions/failovers between either the CLC hosts or the CLC/CC hosts and the NCs

h5. Reducing test times

# Go into DB and tweak the instance update timestamp so we don't die of old age -- orphan the instance immediately after partitioning the NC
# Go into DB and induce specific instance restoration conflicts:
## Public Address Conflict
## Private Network Index Conflict
## Network Tag Conflict
## Volume Attachment Conflict
# Avoid long timeout scenarios through cleverness or hard work, but not patience.
## See linux tcp params in EUCA-6199 related to network timeouts
## Explicitly shutdown connection pools in order to expedite failure detection
## Use {{ip route [add|del] [table [local|main]] [unreachable|blackhole|prohibit|reject] ADDRESS}} to simulate failures (rather than stopping the network and having to wait for the TCP stack to make up its mind).  
## I'll post a script I've been playing around with to survey the behaviour involved; *NOTE* it is clear there are *different* failure behaviours.
## Also, the relevant cases for {{ip route}} being applied are: destination host (blocking the sender) vs remotely (rules setup on a separate router box blocking destination route) vs. locally (rules blocking destination on the sender side). 
## See the subsequent script's main-loop for the cases

A script which survey's the failure behaviour of simulating network failures using {{ip route add [blackhole|unreachable|throw|prohibit] $HOST}}.  See my previous comment for details.  See the script's mainloop to see the comments about the test cases -- they are hardcoded.

* Assumes keyless ssh root@host
* Assumes presence of iproute2, fping, arping
* Requires manual munging in order to change test cases and hosts
* Examples test cases use my hosts.  The list below indicates with an *X* where the routing rule is installed to cause failure.
** 10.0.0.4 --> 10.0.0.254 X-> 54.224.98.241
** 10.0.0.4 ->X 10.0.0.254 --> 54.224.98.241
** 10.0.0.4 X-> 10.0.0.254 --> 54.224.98.241
** 10.0.0.4 ->X 10.0.0.3
** 10.0.0.4 X-> 10.0.0.3

[~decker] I have to say that I may have been lost in your explanation, perhaps because I don't understand the relationship between networks, volumes, and public IP, with Walrus. So, is it fair to say that when there is some routing/ip weirdness, there *may be* some walrus issues? Is that what we need to look for in the field?

[~graziano] I wish I had an easy "yes" answer :)  In brief, I suspect that the management of relations may be prone to partial failures (even though it _shouldn't_ be vis a vis transactions).  So, when we do changes across resource types there are operations which modify one type first followed by another in a separate operation -- some kind of composition of transactions.  The ones which are subject to those kinds of composite transactions are images, security group stuff, and volumes -- and of course instances.  If that suspicion is right then the failures indicated in this ticket would manifest when an ongoing composite-transaction fails partially (which, I think, would take a network partition to happen).

[~decker] but wouldn't be the issue only for the operation 'in flight' when the partition occurs? Or could this be similar to a 'database corruption' and we loose all the table? Is there anything we can do to limit the damages to spread past the 'in-flight' operations?

If the above is true, HA seems to be more dangerous than a downtime for the CLC, in which case the system wouldn't be operational, but at least no data or state would be lost.

This issue was previously scheduled to be worked on in more than one sprint:
* '3.4 Sprint 1' (on board '3.3 Release Board')
* '3.3 Sprint 4' (on board 'Test 3.3 Board')
* '3.3 Sprint 4' (on board 'Copy of 3.3 Release Board')

Starting from JIRA Agile 6.3, an issue can only belong to a single future sprint. Read more about this change: http://docs.atlassian.com/agile/docs-0630/Sprint+Marker+Migration

This issue is now scheduled for future sprint '3.4 Sprint 1' (on board '3.3 Release Board').

If this is incorrect, please update the issue accordingly.

This comment was automatically generated by JIRA. If it is no longer relevant, please feel free to delete it.
We havent seen anything like this in QA. Are there specific steps to reproduce that we should try?
[~viglesias][~kedwards][~hspencer] this issue looks like confirmed as resolved for the latest release. Closing it down. Please re-open if you still see it.
Issues marked fixed in currently released versions of the software. Moving to Closed fixed
